questions.question: What type of fracture is caused by a hammer?
questions.explanation: depressed fracture, where the bone is pushed inward at the point of impact, creating a localized depression or indentation. Depressed Fracture Comminuted Fracture Gutter Fracture Occurs when a fragment of the skull is pushed inward towards the brain. Caused by blows from heavy objects with a small surface (e.g., hammers, bricks). The shape of the depressed area may resemble the object that caused the injury. Variants: Elevated Fracture : One end of the fractured fragment is raised above the skull, while the other is pushed inward. Caused by sharp objects like an axe. Pond Fracture : Seen in infants, this smooth depression occurs without a fracture line, resembling a dent in a ping-pong ball. Caused by obstetrics forceps blade. Involves multiple intersecting fracture lines, breaking the bone into several fragments. Caused by high-impact trauma (e.g., vehicular accidents, crushing injuries). It may occur alongside other fractures (e.g., fissured or depressed fractures). Spider web-like patterns on an X-ray are characteristic of comminuted fractures. In severe cases, bone fragments may penetrate the brain or become displaced. A groove or channel is formed in the skull bone, often due to an oblique bullet wound. Frequently associated with comminuted and depressed fractures of the inner skull table. Bone fragments can cause injury to the meninges or brain. Depressed fracture Comminuted fracture Gutter fracture Ring Fracture (Option D) Motorcyclist Fracture (Hinge Fracture) (Option C) Encircles the foramen magnum at the skull base. Runs from the sella turcica to the petrous ridges and posterior fossa. It can extend to the middle ear and roof of the nose. Transverse fracture at the skull base, splitting it and creating a "hinge" - nodding face sign . It extends from one petrous ridge across the sella turcica to the other petrous ridge. Caused by: Falls landing on feet/buttocks (force transmitted through the spine). Heavy blows to the top of the skull/ vertex. Twisting of the head on the spine. Blows to the occiput or chin. Often caused by side impacts . Ring fracture Hinge fracture Fissured Fracture (Linear Fracture) (Option A) Diastatic Fracture (Sutural Fracture) The most common skull fracture accounts for about 70% of cases. Linear cracks may involve the vertex or skull base. It can affect the full thickness of the bone or just the inner/outer layers. The fracture line is irregular and fine, sometimes hard to detect on X-rays. It runs parallel to the compressive force. No depression of bone fragments. Involves the separation of cranial sutures. More common in children. Often occurs with other skull fractures, especially fissured fractures. Commonly seen at the sagittal suture. Causes: Impact against broad surfaces (e.g., falls or road traffic accidents) Falls on feet or buttocks, transmitting force upwards. Causes: Blunt trauma to the head. Increased intracranial pressure leads to suture separation. Narrow fissure skull fracture Diastatic Fracture

questions.question: A dead body was found with a wound on the neck, with clean-cut edges, crushed tissues along with the disruption of the vertebral bones.Identify the type of wound.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Chop wound Explanation: A chop wound is characterized by: Clean-cut edges (sharp weapon component). Crushed tissues (blunt force component). Disruption of vertebral bones (high-impact force). Mechanism: Caused by heavy, sharp-edged weapons like an axe, machete, or cleaver. Combines both incised (clean edges) and lacerated (crushing) features due to the weight and force involved. Incised wound (Option A): Clean-cut edges without tissue crushing or bone injury. Lacerated wound (Option C): Irregular edges with tissue bridging, caused by blunt trauma. Avulsion (Option D): Tearing away of tissue, often from high-velocity trauma or accidents. Reference: Chop wounds

questions.question: A 12-year-old boy presents with an injury sustained during a football match after being tackled by an opponent. As the casualty medical officer, how would you describe the wound in the case sheet?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Laceration Explanation: The above image and scenario are suggestive of a laceration Laceration is the tearing or splitting of the skin, mucous membranes, muscles, or internal organs due to a shearing or crushing force from a blunt impact over a broad area. When blunt force causes severe bruising and damage to deeper tissues, it is referred to as a crush injury . Characteristics Irregular Margins : Ragged, uneven edges with pointed or blunt ends, often showing small tears. Swallow Tails : Tearing at the ends of lacerations, diverging. Bruising : Seen around the wound, more pronounced in areas impacted at an angle or with downward force. Tissue Bridges : Deeper tissues are unevenly torn, leaving nerve, vessel, and connective tissue bridges. Hair Damage : Crushed hair bulbs; hair and skin tags may be embedded in the wound. Hemorrhage : Less severe bleeding as arteries are crushed and torn irregularly , retracting and allowing blood to clot . Soiling : Debris like mud, wood splinters, sand, glass, or hair can become embedded, carrying medico-legal significance. Wound Gaping : Impact from an angle causes tearing on the opposite side and abrasion on the impact side, leading to gaping. Incorrect Options: Incised wounds (Option A): They have clean, smooth edges and do not show the uneven tearing or bruising present in this case. Abrasions (Option B): They involve superficial skin damage and typically lack deep tissue involvement and significant bruising. Bruise (Option D): A bruise (contusion) is caused by blunt trauma, leading to subcutaneous bleeding without a break in the skin.

questions.question: A middle-aged man was brought to the ER after an assault with a sharp axe. Identify the type of wound.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Chop wound Explanation: The injury from the scenario is suggestive of a chop wound. A chop wound is a deep injury caused by a heavy, sharp object like an axe. It combines features of both an incised wound (sharp edges) and a lacerated wound (underlying tissue damage and crushing effect). Chop wounds/ Slash wounds These are deep gaping wounds inflicted by a blow with the moderately sharp cutting edge of a heavy weapon when applied with significant force. It is a combination of blunt and sharp force injury. Weapons used Hatchet Axe Sword Broad heavy knife Chopper Saber Meat cleaver Features of the wound The axe's lower end (heel) strikes first, leaving a deeper wound than the upper end (toe). It is an incised wound on skin with an underlying communited fracture or deep grove in the bone. Dimensions of the wound correspond to the cross-section of the penetrating blade. Margins are sharp and may have abrasions, bruising, and some lacerations with severe injury to underlying organs. Medicolegal importance Most injuries are homicidal. Frew are accidental by machinery (propeller injuries). Rarely suicidal. Wounds give details of the weapon used and the direction of attack. Chop wound on forehead from a propeller accident Incorrect Options: Incised wound (Option A): An incised wound is caused by a sharp-edged object, such as a knife or blade, and is characterized by clean-cut edges. Lacerated wound (Option C): Lacerated wounds are caused by blunt force trauma, resulting in irregular edges. An axe typically causes more defined sharp edges, making it a chop wound rather than a laceration. Abrasion (Option D): Abrasions are superficial injuries caused by friction or scraping against a rough surface, which is not applicable in the case of an axe assault.

questions.question: A man was working in a field and he suddenly collapsed on a hot summer afternoon. On examination, there were no physical signs of dehydration. His serum electrolyte level was normal. The doctor found that the body temperature was 106 degrees Fahrenheit. Which of the following symptoms is least likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.explanation: Fahrenheit, the symptom that is least likely to be seen in this patient is sweating. Heatstroke is a severe form of heat-related illness characterized by elevated body temperature. Sweating is absent in heat stroke but present in exertional heat stroke Condition Cause Clinical Features Postmortem Findings Heat Stroke Failure of thermoregulation in extreme heat exposure Sudden collapse-loss of consciousness, due to hypotension (Option B) Skin hot, initially wet, then dry (Option A) Hyperventilation- tachycardia Core temp > 40.5°C/104 F Pupils contracted Convulsions Unconsciousness Cerebral dysfunction (Option D) High fever Absence of sweating (Option C) Congested lungs, intrathoracic petechiae (children) Subendocardial hemorrhages Brain congestion, flattened convolutions, petechiae in the 3rd/4th ventricle walls

questions.question: Identify the lesion shown in the image below:
questions.explanation: shown in the image would be Incised-looking laceration. Split lacerations are commonly seen in areas where the skin is close to bone, such as the scalp, with minimal underlying soft tissue. Although the edges may appear sharp, the presence of tissue bridges confirms the diagnosis of a laceration rather than an incised wound. Types of Laceration Split laceration Avulsion laceration Stretch laceration Tear laceration Cut laceration Types of Laceration Split Laceration (Incised looking laceration) These occur when skin is crushed between two objects, such as the scalp being compressed between the skull and a hard surface like the ground or a blunt object. Seen on areas where the skin is close to bone, with minimal underlying tissue E.g., scalp, eyebrows, cheekbones, jaw, iliac crest, perineum, shin. Lacerations without excessive skin crushing can have sharp edges, resembling incised wounds. Also known as incised looking laceration. These are not undermined and show tissue bridges. Avulsion (Shearing Laceration) Caused by a shearing force at an acute angle, detaching skin or organs from their attachments. The shearing and grinding force from a heavy object, like a lorry wheel passing over a limb, can cause the skin to separate from the underlying tissues, a condition known as avulsion or "flaying." This often results in crushed muscles and fractured bones. The detached skin may have extensive abrasions due to the tyre’s

questions.question: Name the type of skull fracture.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Hinge fracture Explanation: The type of skull fracture shown in the image is Hinge fracture. A Hinge fracture involves a break in the skull that allows part of the skull to rotate or pivot around a point, resembling a hinge. This type of fracture typically occurs due to a localized impact or force, often affecting the base or side of the skull. Motorcyclist Fracture (Hinge Fracture) (Option B) Ring Fracture (Option D ruled out) Transverse fracture at the skull base, splitting it and creating a "hinge" - nodding face sign . It extends from one petrous ridge across the sella turcica to the other petrous ridge. Encircles the foramen magnum at the skull base. Runs from the sella turcica to the petrous ridges and posterior fossa. It can extend to the middle ear and roof of the nose. Often caused by side impacts . Caused by: Falls landing on feet/buttocks (force transmitted through the spine). Heavy blows to the top of the skull/ vertex. Twisting of the head on the spine. Blows to the occiput or chin. Hinge fracture Ring fracture Depressed Fracture (Option A ruled out) Occurs when a fragment of the skull is pushed inward towards the brain. Caused by blows from heavy objects with a small surface (e.g., hammers, bricks). The shape of the depressed area may resemble the object that caused the injury. Variants: Elevated Fracture : One end of the fractured fragment is raised above the skull, while the other is pushed inward. Caused by sharp objects like an axe. Pond Fracture : Seen in infants, this smooth depression occurs without a fracture line, resembling a dent in a ping-pong ball. Caused by obstetrics forceps blade. (Option C ruled out)

questions.question: Identify the injury the image below :
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Abrasion Explanation: Abrasion: Abrasion is a superficial injury caused by the removal or damage of the skin's outer layer (epidermis) due to friction or pressure. It is classified into four main types: Scratch Abrasion (Linear Abrasion) Grazed Abrasion (Sliding Abrasion) Mechanism: Caused by tangential (side-to-side) force, producing a long and narrow abrasion. Features: Linear in nature, with length being more significant than width. Examples: Fingernail abrasion, thorn abrasion, and pin abrasion. Mechanism: Occurs when skin slides over a rough surface, resulting in superficial scrapes. Also Known As: Grinding abrasion, gravel rash, brush-burn. Features: Seen in road traffic accidents or falls, especially on exposed areas like knees or elbows. Imprint Abrasion (Patterned Abrasion) Pressure Abrasion (Crushing Abrasion) Mechanism: Results from compressive force applied perpendicular to the skin, leaving a distinct pattern of the object. Also Known As Impact abrasion, contact abrasion, patterned abrasion. Examples: Tyre marks, bite marks Mechanism: Caused by a continuous vertical force applied to the skin, crushing the epidermis. Features: Deeper skin injuries are often seen

questions.question: Paradoxical undressing is seen in :
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Hypothermia Explanation: Hypothermia occurs when the body's core temperature falls below 36°C (96.8°F), leading to paradoxical undressing . This occurs due to disorientation and mental confusion as the body struggles to regulate temperature, causing the victim to undress, which paradoxically increases heat loss. This behavior can be mistaken for evidence of sexual assault or homicide . Hypothermia Definition Core temperature below 36°C (96.8°F) Signs Disorientation Dulling of consciousness Loss of reflex Fall in respiration, heart rate, and blood pressure Red patches and pallor of the skin Edema of the face Stiffness of neck muscles Autopsy findings Patches of pink to brownish-pink discoloration Postmortem staining: Pink/bright red Cyanosis or pallor in extremities ("white deaths") Edema of feet and blistering of skin Stomach: Wischnewsky spots- brownish black colored gastric mucosal ulcers Viscera-congested, hemorrhagic Phenomena seen in hypothermia victims Paradoxical undressing - found undressed due to disorientation which increases heat loss (mistaken for evidence of sexual assault or homicide) ‘Hide and die' syndrome - found in unusual locations resembling an attempt to "hide" or create a protective environment due to mental confusion and a possible hibernation reflex (confused with signs of homicide or robbery) Chilblain (Erythema Pernio) - red, itching skin lesions typically found on extremities due to cold exposure, often accompanied by edema and blistering. Heart stress (Option A) typically refers to conditions that put pressure on the heart, such as heart attacks or heart failure. Paradoxical undressing is not associated with heart stress. It occurs due to hypothermia, where the body loses its ability to regulate temperature properly. Voyeurism (Option B) is a psychological condition where individuals gain sexual pleasure from watching others without their knowledge. It is unrelated to paradoxical undressing, which is a phenomenon occurring due to hypothermia and confusion. LSD overdose (Option D) can cause severe confusion, hallucinations, and altered perceptions, but it does not typically lead to paradoxical undressing. Hypothermia, not LSD overdose, is the primary cause of this phenomenon. Reference: Gautam Biswas Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 3rd edition, pages 263-264

questions.question: Post-mortem examination reveals specific findings. What is this finding known as?
questions.explanation: the fatal injury. These small cuts can be indicative of hesitation , often observed in scenarios of self-infliction or in cases where the victim may have struggled before the lethal wound. Hesitation cuts: Hesitation cuts (also known as tentative cuts or trial wounds) are multiple, small, superficial cuts that typically involve only the skin. These cuts are often found at the beginning of a deeper incised wound. Psychological Aspect : They suggest that the individual may have hesitated while gathering the courage to make a decisive cut. Forensic Observation : In cases of homicidal sharp force injuries, multiple superficial, roughly parallel incised wounds may appear on the neck, often adjacent to a single deep, lethal incised wound, particularly in instances where torture is involved. Grazed abrasion (Option B): Superficial injury caused by a tangential force, resulting in skin being scraped off. Commonly occurs during falls or friction injuries. Laceration (Option C): Irregular tear in the skin caused by blunt force trauma, often accompanied by tissue bridging. Patterned bruise (Option D): Bruises that replicate the shape of the causative object (e.g., belt marks or shoe prints). Seen in cases of physical assault or trauma. Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Gautam Biswas, 3rd Edition, Page 199.

questions.question: The image provided shows a wound. What type of wound is it?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Contusion Explanation A contusion, commonly known as a bruise, results from blunt force trauma causing blood vessels under the skin to rupture. It appears as discoloration of the skin due to subcutaneous bleeding without an open wound. The image likely shows this characteristic discoloration. Abrasion (Option B): An abrasion involves superficial damage to the skin, such as scraping, which removes the epidermis. It does not typically involve subcutaneous bleeding as seen in the image. Laceration (Option C): Lacerations are irregular tears in the skin caused by blunt or sharp trauma. They are characterized by jagged wound edges, which are not visible in the provided image. Stab wound (Option D): A stab wound is caused by a pointed object penetrating the skin. It is characterized by a deep, narrow wound, which is inconsistent with the image. Mechanism of injury of contusions A contusion or bruise is a leak of blood into the tissues due to the rupture of blood vessels (veins, venules, arterioles) caused due to injury by a blunt object. Some blunt objects that can cause contusions are fist, stones, sticks, bar, whip, hammer, axe, wooden handle, poker, foot with shoe or boot, etc. Factors influencing the formation of bruises Condition and type of tissues Vascular and loose tissues may form large bruises even with a small degree of violence. Examples: face, vulva, and scrotum. Firm fibrous tissues, strongly supported tissues, and those covered by a thick dermis produce a comparatively small bruise for moderate trauma. Examples: abdomen, back, scalp, palms, and soles. Injury of tissues over bony surfaces shows prominent bruising. Age Children bruise easily. Older people bruise easily. Gender Women bruise more easily than men. Obese people bruise easily due to the high volume of subcutaneous tissue. Colour of the skin Bruising is more easily visible in fair-skinned people than in dark-skinned people. Contusions are better felt in dark-skinned people than seen. Natural diseases Prominent bruising is seen with minor trauma in patients with: Arteriosclerosis Whooping cough in children due to violent coughing can cause bruising Purpura hemorrhagica Leukemia Hemophilia Scurvy Vitamin K Prothrombin deficiency Phosphorus poisoning Older persons on systemic steroids Gravity shifting of the blood In deep bruises, blood tracks along the fascial planes and may cause the bruise at a different site. This is called ectopic bruising or percolated or migratory contusion . Examples: Spectacle hematoma or black eye in blunt trauma to the forehead. Bruise behind ear due to basal skull fracture ( Battle’s sign ). Bruise in the neck from fracture of the jaw. Bruise around the ankle from a kick on the calf. Learning Objective:

questions.question: Identify the pattern of abrasion shown in the image below.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Ligature mark Explanation A ligature mark is pressure abrasion caused by the application of a constricting force using a cord-like object (e.g., rope, wire) around the neck. It is commonly observed in cases of hanging or strangulation. Characteristics include a continuous or interrupted band-like mark, which may show the texture or pattern of the ligature material. The location and orientation of the mark can help distinguish hanging from manual strangulation. Pressure abrasion (Option A): Caused by sustained pressure of a blunt object against the skin. Graze abrasion (Option B): Occurs when the skin is scraped against a rough surface. Imprint abrasion (Option D): A patterned abrasion caused when a textured object presses into the skin, leaving a distinct impression. Learning Objective: Postmortem Abrasion Vs Antemortem Abrasion Feature Postmortem Abrasion Antemortem Abrasion Image Intra-vital reaction or congestion Absent Present Site Typically found on bony prominences Can occur on any part of the body Color of abrasion Yellowish-white or pale Reddish-brown to dark brown Scab formation Absent or minimal Present and well-formed Exudates Less or absent Increased (due to inflammatory reaction) Elevation (Scab) Less raised More raised due to active healing Bleeding/ Color changes No active bleeding Active bleeding with clot formation Healing process No healing process Healing starts with inflammation

questions.question: Which of the following injuries is not expected in a person brought to the hospital with a history of a road traffic accident (RTA)?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Chop wound Explanation: Chop wounds are deep, incised wounds caused by heavy, sharp-edged weapons like axes or machetes. Chop/ Slash wound Deep, gaping wounds caused by a blow from a sharp-cutting edge of a heavy weapon (e.g., hatchet, axe, sword, chopper). Wound size corresponds to the cross-section of the blade. Undermining occurs in the direction of chop . The heel (lower end) of the axe typically strikes first , leading to deeper wounds than the toe (upper end). The deeper end indicates the assailant's position . Clean slicing through bone at impact; rebound can create irregular fragments; may lead to complete or incomplete amputations. Mostly homicidal injuries to exposed body parts (head, face, neck, extremities) Incorrect Options: Contusion (Option A): Contusions (bruises) are commonly observed in RTAs due to blunt force trauma sustained during the impact or collision. Abrasions (Option B): Abrasions are also frequent in RTAs, resulting from friction or scraping of the skin against rough surfaces, such as the road or vehicle parts. Laceration (Option C): Lacerations, or irregular tears in the skin, are often seen in RTAs, especially in cases involving glass shards, sharp edges of vehicles, or other objects. Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, K. S. Narayan Reddy, 35th Edition, Page 144, 149

questions.question: The dead body of a 30-year-old male drowning victim was brought in for autopsy. Upon examination, multiple cuts were observed on the victim's arm. What finding is likely to be seen in this scenario?
questions.explanation: against an assailant, they might sustain what are known as defense wounds. These wounds typically occur on the flexor surface of the forearm, as individuals instinctively raise their arms to protect their face and body during an attack. The cuts on the victim's arm in this scenario are consistent with defense wounds, suggesting that the victim was trying to shield themselves from harm. Incorrect Options: Option B - Self-inflicted injury: Self-inflicted injuries are wounds that a person intentionally inflicts upon themselves. These injuries might result from self-harm or suicide attempts. However, in the given scenario, the presence of multiple cuts on the victim's arm does not necessarily suggest self-inflicted injury, as the location and pattern of the cuts seem more indicative of defensive actions rather than self-infliction. Option C - Accidental cut wound from falling: An accidental cut wound from falling might result from an individual accidentally coming into contact with a sharp object while falling. However, this scenario is less likely in this case because the presence of multiple cuts on the flexor surface of the arm is not consistent with typical patterns of injuries sustained during a fall. Option D - Washer-women hands: "Washer-women hands" is a term used to describe the appearance of the fingers and hands after prolonged exposure to water, like during laundry work. This option is not relevant to the scenario described, as it does not explain the presence of multiple cuts on the victim's arm or the context of the drowning incident. Reference: .

questions.question: A person got stabbed in his anterior thigh and died. His body was brought for postmortem. What type of injury is this?
questions.explanation: tissues or body cavities. In this case, the stab wound to the anterior thigh involves a sharp object penetrating the skin and underlying tissues, making it a penetrating wound. Stab wound/Punctured wound These are inflicted by penetration with long, narrow instruments having pointed (sometimes blunt) ends into the depth of the body, which is deeper than its length and width. Weapons used Knife (most common) Pieces of glass (broken glass bottle) Scissors Screwdrivers Pens Ice picks Forks Types of stab wounds Puncture wound: (Option C) Soft tissues are involved Penetrating wound: Enters a body cavity or a viscus Perforating wound: Through-and-through puncture wounds The weapon enters the body from one side and comes out the other The wound of entry is larger than the exit Significance of the wound dimensions Length is slightly less than the width of the weapon due to the stretching of the skin. Breadth is more than the thickness of weapon due to gaping. Depth , the greatest dimension of the wound, corresponds to the length of the weapon's blade, which has completely entered the body without perforation. Margins or edges of the wound are clean cut with usually no abrasion or bruising. Margins by a pointed or conical weapon have lacerated edges If the hilt guard of the weapon strikes the skin, a regular, sharp, and well-defined patterned abrasion or bruising is formed Incised wound (Option A): An incised wound is a clean cut caused by a sharp object (e.g., a razor or knife) and is typically longer than it is deep. A stab wound is deeper than it is long, so it does not qualify as an incised wound. Blunt force injury (Option D): This involves trauma caused by a blunt object (e.g., a bat or hammer) and does not involve penetration of the skin or tissues. A stab wound is caused by a sharp object, not blunt force.

questions.question: A 3-year-old child presented with multiple burn injuries involving the entire head, neck & upper limb. What is the percentage of burn?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) 25-30% Explanation: In children, the total body surface area (TBSA) percentages differ from adults due to the larger head-to-body ratio. According to the Rule of Nines adjusted for children and the Lund and Browder chart: The entire head and neck account for approximately 18% of the TBSA in a 3-year-old child. Each upper limb accounts for approximately 9% of the TBSA. Adding these together: 18% (head and neck) + 9% (one upper limb) = 27% According to the Wallace rule of 9, this is how the area burned is calculated: Adults Children Infants Head & neck 9% 18% 20% Front of chest & abdominal wall 9 x 2 = 18% 18% 10 x 2 = 20% Back of chest & abdominal wall 9 x 2 = 18% 18% 10 x 2 = 20% Lower limb 18 x 2 = 36% 13.5 x 2 = 27% 10 x 2 = 20% Upper limb 9 x 2 = 18% 18% 10 x 2 = 20% Perineum 1% 1% 40-44% (Option B): This value overestimates the burn area. A 40-44% burn would imply involvement of larger or additional body areas beyond the head, neck, and one upper limb, such as parts of the trunk or both upper limbs. 18-20% (Option C): This value roughly corresponds to the head and neck alone, without including the upper limb. Since the upper limb is also involved, the percentage should be higher. 5-10% (Option D): This severely underestimates the burn size. The entire head and neck alone exceed 10%, so including one upper limb must be substantially more. Reference: SRB 6th edition, page 122

questions.question: Leading questions can be asked in?
questions.explanation: response. These questions are typically allowed during cross-examination but not during examination-in-chief or re-examination, except in special circumstances. Examination of Witness : The below sequence is based on the Sec. 138 IEA. Oath ↓ Chief examination ↓ Cross-examination ↓ Re-examination Aspect Examination-in-Chief (Direct Examination) Cross-Examination Re-Examination Conducted By Party who calls the witness (e.g., public prosecutor) Opposing party (typically defense) Party who called the witness Purpose Present all relevant facts Provide expert interpretation if applicable Challenge witness's credibility Elicit favorable facts Test accuracy Clarify issues raised during cross-examination Leading Questions Not allowed unless the witness is declared hostile (Option D) Allowed ( Sec. 146 BSA ) Not allowed (Option B) Nature of Questions Open-ended questions to elicit narrative Can include leading questions to control the narrative Generally clarifying questions Time Limit Typically structured and may have time constraints No set time limit; may last for hours or even days Generally limited to clarification purposes Judicial Oversight Judge may intervene to ensure questions are relevant and not leading Court can disallow indecent or scandalous questions (Sec. 154, BSA) Judge monitors to ensure focus remains on clarification Anytime (Option C): This is incorrect because leading questions are restricted during examination-in-chief and re-examination. Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, K S Narayan Reddy, OP Murty, 35th Edition, Page. 10, 11. Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Gautam Biswas, 3rd Edition, Page. 51. https://bprd.nic.in/uploads/pdf/BNS.pdf

questions.question: Sequence of rigor mortis is?
questions.explanation: muscles and progresses to the larger muscle groups. The sequence generally begins with the muscles of the face and neck, followed by the upper limbs, and then extends to the trunk and lower limbs. Therefore, rigor mortis progresses from the head and upper parts of the body downwards towards the feet. Incorrect Options: Option A - Center to periphery: Rigor mortis does not progress from the center of the body to the periphery. It starts in the head and moves towards the feet, not the central parts to the outer extremities. Option C - Foot to head: Rigor mortis does not start in the feet and move upwards to the head. It starts in the head and progresses downwards towards the feet. Option D - Simultaneously: Rigor mortis does not occur simultaneously in all parts of the body. It progresses in a specific sequence, starting with the head and upper body, then moving downwards.

questions.question: Identify the bullet range
questions.explanation: this indicates a close-range shot. Blackening is caused by the deposition of soot and gunpowder residue from the burning propellant, while tattooing is due to the impact of unburned powder particles. These signs are typically seen when the muzzle is relatively close to the target, usually within a few feet. Incorrect Options: Option A - Distant range: At a distant range, the wound would not exhibit blackening or tattooing because the gunpowder residues would not have had a chance to settle on the skin. Distant range wounds usually present with a clean entry wound without additional residues. Option B - Close contact: Close contact wounds are typically characterized by a much more severe pattern, such as a star-shaped wound with burning and possibly charring of the skin. The presence of blackening and tattooing suggests a somewhat less extreme range, but still close. Option D - Cannot be predicted: The presence of blackening and tattooing can indeed predict the bullet range with a reasonable degree of certainty. Therefore, this option is not accurate as the gunshot range can be estimated based on these features.

questions.question: A 35-year-old female patient is admitted to the emergency department following an accidental burn incident. On examination, it is noted that she has sustained burn injuries to her right upper limb, the entire right lower limb, and the entire front and back of her abdomen. Based on the rule of nine, what is the estimated percentage of her total body surface area (TBSA) that is burned?
questions.explanation: Calculation: Right upper limb: 9% Entire right lower limb: 18% Front of abdomen: 9% Back of abdomen: 9% Total = 9% + 18% + 9% + 9% = 45% Wallace rule of nine: Body Part Estimated TBSA Adults Labeled Image Entire left arm 9% Entire right arm 9% Head & neck 9% Chest 9% Back of chest 9% Abdomen 9% Back of Abdomen 9% Perineum 1% Entire left leg 18% Entire right leg 18% Reference: Goutam Biswas Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 3rd edition, pages 268, 269

questions.question: Which of the following is the bleeding vessel in extradural hemorrhage?
questions.explanation: extradural Hemorrhage (epidural Hemorrhage) is the middle meningeal artery. Intracranial haemorrhages The first layer is the skull vault (cranium), followed by the dura mater, arachnoid mater, pia mater, and brain tissue (cerebrum). The space between the skull and dura contains the middle meningeal artery. The middle meningeal artery is most prominent at the pterion, the point where the frontal, parietal, sphenoid, and temporal bones meet. Space and Hemorrhages Location Blood vessel involved Epidural Space/ Hemorrhage Between the skull vault and dura mater. The collection of blood here leads to epidural hematoma. Middle meningeal artery (Option A) Subdural Space/ Hemorrhage Between the arachnoid and dura mater. The collection of blood here leads to subdural hematoma. Bridging veins (which drain into the dural venous sinus) (Option B ruled out) Subarachnoid Space/ Hemorrhage Between the arachnoid and pia mater Arteries of the circle of Willis (Middle cerebral artery, Anterior communicating artery -most commonly) (Option C ruled out) Anterior cerebral artery (Option D) is not involved in extradural hemorrhage

questions.question: During measurement of a rifled barrel weapon, the caliber depends on?
questions.explanation: refers to the diameter of a rifled firearm's barrel, specifically measured between opposing lands. This measurement, typically expressed in inches or millimetres, is crucial for linking a bullet to a specific firearm. Rifled Firearms: Rifled firearms have a bore characterised by a series of grooves that spiral along the barrel's length. These grooves (Option B) , known as "rifling," alternate with raised areas called "lands." The caliber is determined by measuring the distance between these lands. (Option A) The direction of rifling can be either right (clockwise) or left (counter-clockwise), with most handguns featuring a right-hand twist. As the bullet travels through the barrel, it engages with the lands and grooves, imparting a spin that stabilises its flight and leaves distinctive markings on the bullet, which serve as identifiers for the firearm. Number of lead pellets (Option C) Bore or Gauge: It is used for smooth bore weapons. The number of balls/pellets of equal size/weight made from 1 pound lead (454g) 12 bore = 12 balls Mass and velocity (Option D) of a projectile fired from a rifled barrel weapon are important factors in its performance, they are not used directly to determine the caliber of the weapon

questions.question: Most common organ involved in seat-belt injury is?
questions.explanation: ideally is the mesentery. Since the given options do not contain mesentery the best option here is hollow viscus. Seat belts: Restraints the body against severe deceleration and hence preventing impact from windscreen, steering wheel and other obstruction. Though it slows down deceleration, it can jam at a certain point leading to injuries. Follows Inertia-reel mechanism. Primarily of two types: Shoulder diagonal (most commonly used in vehicles) Lap strap (aircrafts) Seat Belt injuries: Patterned contusion (known as Seat belt sign ) Drivers: starts from the right shoulder Passengers: starts from the left shoulder Intra-abdominal (deceleration- compression) Mesentery - most commonly affected (Option D) Small intestine: DJ flexure (primary),Ileocaecal junction (secondary) Liver, Spleen, Pancreas (Option A, B and C) Vertebral injuries (distraction- compression) Distraction(separation of joint): seen on posterior side Compression: seen on anterior side Chance fracture: fracture involving all 3 columns of spine Seat belt syndrome Seat belt sign + intra-abdominal injuries + vertebral injuries

questions.question: The most common organ injuries in air blast shock waves will be?
questions.explanation: the tympanic membrane (TM); given that the options do not contain TM, the next best answer is the lung. Blast lung is a primary blast injury. The shock wave causes immediate lung injury, characterized by the rupture of alveolar capillaries. Blast Injury: Extent of Damage Greater damage compared to bullet injuries due to complex blast waves. Explosion pressure wave exceeds 1000 pounds per square inch, involving incident and reflected pressure. Factors Causing Damage High-pressure wave impact. Mechanical, chemical, and thermal injuries. Inhalation of toxic gases and smoke. Types of blast injuries: Air Blast Injuries Underwater Blast Injuries Most commonly injured: Tympanic membrane (ear) - Rupture and middle ear damage are common Tympanic membrane (ear) - More likely to occur when the head is submerged. Gastrointestinal tract - When the head is not submerged. Most severely injured: Lungs - Blast lung injury is a common cause of delayed mortality and can cause pulmonary contusion, air embolism, and other damage Gastrointestinal tract - Underwater blasts can cause more severe GI injuries due to pressure effects on hollow organs Intestine, kidney, and heart (Options A, C, and D) are not the most common injuries in air blast Reference: Blast Injuries - PMC (nih.gov) Blast Injuries - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf (nih.gov) Explosives and Blast Injuries - Injuries; Poisoning - MSD Manual Professional Edition (msdmanuals.com) Human Injury Criteria for Underwater Blasts

questions.question: During a forensic autopsy, a gunshot victim is examined, and the doctor observes that the firearm injury has a stellate shape. What will be the range of gunshot?
questions.explanation: contact with the victim's skin at the time of firing. This results in the deposition of soot, unburned powder particles, and even possible charring around the entrance wound. The gases and particles from the gunpowder can cause the surrounding skin to exhibit a stellate or star-shaped pattern due to the pressure and heat. Incorrect Options: Option A - Close shot: A close shot refers to a gunshot that is fired from a relatively short distance, usually within a few inches to a few feet. In a close shot, there might be stippling or soot deposition around the entrance wound, but the injury would not typically exhibit a stellate (star-shaped) appearance. Option C - Near shot: A near shot, also known as a close intermediate shot, refers to a gunshot fired from a short distance but not in direct contact with the skin. The range is usually a few inches to a few feet. This might result in stippling or powder tattooing around the entrance wound due to the impact of unburned gunpowder particles on the skin. However, it is less likely to produce a stellate wound pattern as seen in contact shots. Option D - Distant shot: A distant shot is fired from a considerable distance, and the effects on the body are determined by the range of fire. At a greater distance, the bullet's energy dissipates, and there may be no stippling or soot deposition around the entrance wound. The wound tends to be cleaner and smaller compared to closer shots. A stellate wound pattern is unlikely to be present in a distant shot.

questions.question: A 42 year old patient, a case of road traffic accident presented with EDH due to involvement of Middle Meningeal Artery. Where will the impact of collision be?
questions.explanation: to involvement of the Middle Meningeal Artery is likely to occur at the pterion. The pterion is a small, delicate area on the side of the skull where four bones come together: the frontal bone, the parietal bone, the temporal bone, and the sphenoid bone. This area is particularly vulnerable to traumatic injury due to its thin bone structure and the presence of the Middle Meningeal Artery, which runs just beneath the skull in this region. Trauma to the pterion can lead to a rupture of the Middle Meningeal Artery, causing bleeding between the dura mater and the skull, resulting in an epidural hematoma. Incorrect Options: Option B - Angle of mandible: The angle of the mandible is the outermost point of the lower jawbone. While trauma to this area can cause facial injuries, it is not directly associated with the development of an epidural hematoma due to involvement of the Middle Meningeal Artery. Option C - Lambdoid suture: The lambdoid suture is the joint between the occipital bone (back of the skull) and the parietal bones. Trauma to this area can result in injuries to the posterior part of the skull, but it is not typically associated with epidural hematomas involving the Middle Meningeal Artery. Option D - Nasion: The nasion is the intersection point between the frontal bone and the two nasal bones. Trauma to this area can lead to facial injuries, but it is not directly associated with the development of an epidural hematoma due to involvement of the Middle Meningeal Artery.

questions.question: Which of the following characteristics is not typically associated with a true bruise?

options.B: Progression of the color of bruise over time

questions.explanation: more characteristic of artificial bruises caused by substances that irritate the skin. Incorrect Options: Option A. Negative chemical tests : True bruises usually test negative for the presence of certain chemicals that might be used to create artificial bruises. This is consistent with the definition of a true bruise, which results from the extravasation of blood due to blunt force trauma, not chemical irritation . Option B. Progression of the color of bruise over time : One of the hallmark characteristics of true bruises is the progression of color changes over time due to the breakdown of hemoglobin in the tissue. This progression typically goes from red or purple to blue, green, yellow, and finally fading away . .Option C. Irregular margins : True bruises often have irregular, diffuse margins due to the spread of blood within the tissues. This is in contrast to artificial bruises, which typically have well-defined, regular margins due to the application method of the irritant substance . Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: During the examination of a victim of assault , you notice a wound with ragged, irregular and uneven margins with tears diverging at an angle from the end of the main wound and typical swallowtails. Bleeding from this wound is not significant and shows crushed blood vessels and hair bulbs . You would document this wound as a/an.
questions.explanation: wound due to its ragged, irregular, and uneven margins with tears diverging at an angle from the end of the main wound and typical ‘swallowtails ’. Bleeding from this wound is not significant and shows crushed blood vessels and hair bulbs . Lacerated wounds are typically caused by blunt force trauma and have an irregular shape with jagged margins . They can also be caused by tearing, such as in cases of dog bites or machinery accidents. Therefore, the wound should be documented as a lacerated wound. Incorrect Options: Option A - Incised wound: An incised wound typically has clean and sharp margins and is caused by a sharp-edged instrument like a knife. The edges of an incised wound are not ragged, irregular, or uneven, and there are no tears diverging at an angle from the end of the main wound or "swallow tails." Option B - Chopped wound : A chopped wound is a type of wound caused by a heavy, sharp-edged object, such as an axe or a machete. It typically has a clean, straight edge with minimal tissue damage. Option C - Stab wound : A stab wound typically has a narrow and deep wound track with straight or slightly curved margins, and a clean and smooth wound surface. It is caused by a pointed object such as a knife, dagger, or ice pick penetrating the skin and underlying tissues.

questions.question: Which of the following is true about exhumation?

options.A: The executive magistrate can order for exhumation
options.C: Postmortem can be done on exhumated body

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A - The executive magistrate can order for exhumation Exhumation - It is digging out of an already buried body legally from the grave exhumation is done only when there is written order from executive magistrate. The body can be exhumated by any government doctor. Incorrect Option: Option B Police can order for exhumation : This statement is incorrect Option C Postmortem can be done on exhumated body : Autopsies can be performed on exhumated bodies Option D CrPC 174 is related to exhumation : CrPC 176 is related to exhumation Reference: .

questions.question: During the examination of injury, hair bulbs are noted to be crushed. The probable type of wound is:
questions.explanation: the underlying hair bulbs. It often results from blunt force trauma, which can cause compression and crushing of the hair bulbs . Crushed hair bulbs indicate a significant force applied to the area, consistent with a laceration. Characteristics of Lacerations: Trauma: Blunt trauma, may be heavy Damage: 3-Dimensional injury Margins: Irregular Floor: Vessels, nerve, and hair bulb are crushed. Structures: Epidermis +dermis + subcutaneous tissue. Swallow tail, tearing at the end, diverging. Tissue bridges and tissue fragments connect each other from the margin. Bleeding comparatively due to crushed blood vessels. Incorrect Options: Option A - Abrasions: Abrasions typically involve superficial damage to the skin without significant underlying tissue injury. They do not usually cause crushing of hair bulbs. Option C - Stab injuries: Stab injuries are caused by a pointed object piercing the skin. While they may cause damage to the underlying tissues, they do not typically result in crushed hair bulbs. Option D - None: This option is incorrect because the description in the question indicates a specific type of wound characterized by crushed hair bulbs corresponding to a laceration. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: In alleged history of gunshot injury , there is burning, blackening, tattooing around the wound . The injury is:
questions.explanation: of the firearm is in close proximity to the body. In such cases, the burning, blackening, and tattooing of the skin around the wound are commonly observed. These characteristics are due to the presence of unburned gunpowder particles and hot gasses discharged from the firearm. Incorrect Options: Option B - Close shot exit wound : In close shot exit wounds, the burning, blackening, and tattooing effects are usually not present. Close shot exit wounds are characterized by an irregular or stellate appearance, as the bullet exits the body and causes tissue disruption. Option C - Distant shot entry wound: In distant shot entry wounds, there is a significant distance between the muzzle of the firearm and the body. The effects of burning, blackening, and tattooing are not typically observed in such cases. Distant shot entry wounds may appear as small, circular or oval-shaped holes without the characteristics associated with close-range shots. Option D - Distant shot exit wound : Similar to distant shot entry wounds, distant shot exit wounds do not exhibit the effects of burning, blackening, and tattooing. These exit wounds are often characterized by a smaller size compared to close shot exit wounds. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: What is bullet wipe ?
questions.explanation: left behind on a target when a bullet passes through it. This residue is primarily composed of substances such as soot, lubricants, and metal particles that are present in the barrel of the gun. Incorrect Options: Option B - Blackening : Blackening typically refers to the darkening or discoloration of a surface due to various factors such as oxidation, charring, or exposure to heat. Option C - Gutter fracture of the skull : Gutter fracture is a term used to describe a specific type of fracture in the skull, characterized by a groove or channel-like indentation. Option D - Tattooing : Tattooing, in the context of firearms, refers to the deposition of gunpowder particles or other debris onto the skin when a firearm is discharged at close range. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: All of the following statements are true about the given condition except :

options.A: Swabs should be taken immediately after moistening with sterile water
options.B: It is most commonly caused by incisors and canines
options.C: There are fewer chances of bacterial infection

questions.explanation: polymicrobial infection by organisms such as Staphylococcus spp., Streptococcus spp., and Eikenella corrodens . Hence antibiotics are recommended. Incorrect Options: Option A - Swabs should be taken immediately after moistening with sterile water: It is recommended to moisten swabs with sterile water before sampling. Moistening the swabs helps in better collection of potential biological material, such as saliva or cells. Option B - It is most commonly caused by incisors and canines: These teeth are more likely to leave identifiable patterns and impressions in a bite mark. Option D - Tetanus vaccination should be given: This statement is true. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: Bullet fingerprinting involve:
questions.explanation: analyze the unique markings left on bullets or cartridge cases by the firearm used to discharge them. Primary markings include the lands and grooves on the inside of the barrel, which leave distinct striations on the bullet or cartridge case as it passes through the barrel. These primary markings are the key elements that make each firearm's tool marks unique. Secondary markings, may be present on a bullet or cartridge case due to factors such as the firing mechanism, extractor, or ejector of the firearm . When analyzing a bullet or cartridge case, forensic experts examine both the primary and secondary markings to compare them with test-fired bullets or cartridge cases from suspect firearms Incorrect Options: Option A - Primary markings: Primary markings alone do not encompass the complete analysis involved in bullet fingerprinting. Option B - Secondary markings: Secondary markings alone are also not sufficient for bullet fingerprinting analysis. Option D - None: None is incorrect because bullet fingerprinting does involve the examination of both primary and secondary markings. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: Name the type of skull fracture .
questions.explanation: divided in half, the specific type of skull fracture is known as a "hinge fracture." A hinge fracture is a specific subtype of basilar skull fracture, which involves a separation or splitting of the base of the skull along a hinge-like mechanism. Incorrect Options: Option A - Depressed fracture: A depressed fracture is a type of skull fracture where the bone fragments are depressed or pushed inward. It does not correspond to the given image. Option C - Pond fracture: Pond fracture is not a recognized term for a specific type of skull fracture. Option D - Comminuted fracture: Comminuted fracture refers to a fracture in which the bone is fragmented into multiple pieces. It does not correspond to the given image. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: Identify the injury the image below :
questions.explanation: is a superficial injury that occurs when the skin is scraped or rubbed against a rough surface, resulting in the removal of the superficial layers of skin. It typically appears as a shallow, irregular-shaped wound with a reddish or pinkish color. Incorrect Options: Option B - Laceration: A laceration is a type of injury characterized by a deep cut or tear in the skin and underlying tissues. It typically has clean or irregular edges. Option C - Bruise : A bruise is a discoloration of the skin caused by the rupture of blood vessels beneath the skin surface. It appears as a reddish, purple, or blue mark and is often the result of blunt force trauma ,it does not involve the removal of skin layers. Option D - Imprint: An imprint refers to a pattern or mark left on the skin as a result of contact with an object or surface.

questions.question: Paradoxical undressing is seen in :
questions.explanation: cases of severe hypothermia. Hypothermia is a condition characterized by a dangerously low body temperature, usually below 35 degrees Celsius (95 degrees Fahrenheit). This behavior is thought to result from the disorientation and confusion caused by hypothermia, as well as the dilation of blood vessels near the skin's surface, which can create a false sensation of warmth. Incorrect Options: Option A - Heart stress : It is not associated with paradoxical undressing. Option B - Voyeurism : Voyeurism is a paraphilic disorder characterized by an individual's sexual interest and pleasure derived from observing others without their consent. It is unrelated to paradoxical undressing. Option D - LSD overdose : Overdosing on LSD can cause a variety of physical and psychological effects, but paradoxical undressing is not a known symptom. Reference: Prepladder Notes
